DOCNAME: CASE OF P.M. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 14+P1-1;No violation of Art. 13;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . DATE , the applicant lived in a stable relationship with Miss NORP They never married .
CARDINAL . On DATE , Miss D. had a daughter . The applicant was registered as father on the birth certificate .

CARDINAL . In DATE , the applicant and Miss NORP separated . On DATE , they entered into a Deed of Separation by which the applicant undertook to pay DATE maintenance of QUANTITY ( GBP ) for his daughter . In the DATE tax year , he paid ORG CARDINAL under the ORG . The sum increased over time in accordance with the applicant ’s increase in earnings . Since DATE , the applicant has made DATE maintenance payments of ORG CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . For DATE , the applicant was granted relief on his self - assessment tax return for the maintenance payments made under the ORG . The Government state that this was an error by ORG . In DATE , the applicant put in a further claim to deduct these maintenance payments . This would have reduced his income tax liability by GBP CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . NORP By letter dated DATE , the Inland Revenue refused the claim for tax relief in respect of the maintenance payments : “ because you were never married to your daughter ’s mother . ”
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the refusal to a tax tribunal , namely ORG for ORG , invoking the provisions of the Convention .
CARDINAL . A hearing took place on DATE . The applicant was unrepresented . On TIME of the hearing , counsel for ORG presented him with a large file of the authorities on which ORG sought to rely .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG rejected his appeal , primarily on the ground that LAW DATE did not apply to the case as it had only come into force on DATE after DATE in question .
CARDINAL . Miss NORP married during the DATE tax year , on DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINALB of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act DATE , as it applied in DATE of assessment DATE , provided for the deduction of “ qualifying maintenance payments ” . According to section CARDINALB(CARDINAL ) :
( CARDINAL ) In this section ‘ qualifying maintenance payment’ means a periodical payment which -
( a ) is made under an order made by a court in a member ORG or under a written agreement the law applicable to which is the law of a member ORG ...
( b ) is made by CARDINAL of the parties to a marriage ( including a marriage which has been dissolved or annulled ) either -
( i ) to or for the benefit of the other party and for the maintenance of the other party , or
( ii ) to the other party for the maintenance by the other party of any child of the family ,
( c ) is due at a time when -
( i ) the CARDINAL parties are not a married couple living together and
( ii ) the party to whom or for whose benefit the payment is made has not remarried , and
( d ) is not a payment in respect of which relief from tax is available to the person making the payment under any provision of the Income Tax Acts other than this section . ”

CARDINAL . Prior to amendment of the legislation in DATE , married couples who divorced or separated and unmarried couples who separated from one another were in the same position as regarded the deductibility of payments made under LAW . The explanation for allowing the deduction to continue in respect of previously married couples as stated in a ORG by Her Majesty ’s ORG was :

“ A man maintaining his ex - wife ( or vice versa ) will get tax relief on the payments he makes , up to a limit equal to the difference between the married allowance and the single allowance ... This recognises the cost of helping to support an ex - wife and maintain a second household . On present experience , this limit will more than cover the majority of payments to ex - wives and ex - husbands . ”
CARDINAL . In DATE the availability of this deduction has been withdrawn from all but those aged DATE or more .

CARDINAL . Since LAW DATE ( “ the CSA ” ) , it has been Government policy that parents ( predominantly fathers ) separated from their children should be responsible for their children ’s maintenance , irrespective of their marital status . The ORG gives ORG mandatory powers to compel an absent father to give information about his finances , to assess the amount of contribution and to compel enforcement of the contributions .
